Pre-Game Insights: Brazil will resume their 2026 World Cup qualifying campaign when they welcome Ecuador to Estadio Major Antonio Couto Pereira on Friday.
Brazil boss Dorival Junior experienced disappointment in his first tournament in charge of the national team after being eliminated in the quarter-finals of the Copa America.
Despite an underwhelming tournament, Dorival has not lost in regulation time in any of his eight matches in charge.
Brazil began their qualifying campaign with back-to-back wins and a draw against Venezuela, followed by three defeats against Uruguay, Colombia, and Argentina.
Brazil will be confident of taking something from Friday's contest against Ecuador, having avoided defeat in each of their last 12 head-to-head matches.
Ecuador also experienced penalty-shootout disappointment in the quarter-finals of the 2024 Copa America.
Felix Sanchez left his post following Ecuador's Copa America exit and was replaced by Sebastian Beccacece.

Ecuador have put together a five-game unbeaten run in World Cup qualifying and are sitting one place above Brazil despite a three-point deduction for fielding an ineligible player in the previous qualifying cycle.
Brazil are without Neymar, who is recovering from an anterior cruciate ligament injury.
Borussia Dortmund's Yan Couto and Manchester City's Savinho have withdrawn from Brazil's squad due to injury.
Real Madrid defender Eder Militao has been ruled out for the next two fixtures after sustaining a thigh injury.
Dorival has called up 17-year-old Palmeiras attacker Estevao Willian.
With Raphinha suspended, Dorival could select an all-Real Madrid forward line of Rodrygo, Vinicius Junior, and Endrick.
Ecuador are unable to call upon defender Christian Ramirez due to an ankle injury.
Brighton & Hove Albion's Pervis Estupinan has returned to the fold and is expected to start against Brazil.
Ecuador's all-time leading scorer Enner Valencia will spearhead the attack.
